HODMDÂ¶

Derived module from dmdbase.py for higher order dmd.

Reference: - S. L Clainche, J. M. Vega, Higher Order Dynamic Mode Decomposition. Journal on Applied Dynamical Systems, 16(2), 882-925, 2017.

HODMD.atilde Get the reduced Koopman operator A, called A tilde.
HODMD.dmd_timesteps Get the timesteps of the reconstructed states.
HODMD.dynamics Get the time evolution of each mode.
HODMD.eigs Get the eigenvalues of A tilde.
HODMD.fit Compute the Dynamic Modes Decomposition to the input data.
HODMD.modes Get the matrix containing the DMD modes, stored by column.
HODMD.original_timesteps Get the timesteps of the original snapshot.
HODMD.plot_eigs Plot the eigenvalues.
HODMD.plot_modes_2D Plot the DMD Modes.
HODMD.plot_snapshots_2D Plot the snapshots.
HODMD.reconstructed_data Get the reconstructed data.
HODMD.snapshots Get the original input data.
class HODMD(svd_rank=0, tlsq_rank=0, exact=False, opt=False, d=1)[source]

Bases: pydmd.dmdbase.DMDBase

Higher Order Dynamic Mode Decomposition

Parameters:
  • svd_rank (int) – rank truncation in SVD. If 0, the method computes the optimal rank and uses it for truncation; if positive number, the method uses the argument for the truncation; if -1, the method does not compute truncation.
  • tlsq_rank (int) – rank truncation computing Total Least Square. Default is 0, that means TLSQ is not applied.
  • exact (bool) – flag to compute either exact DMD or projected DMD. Default is False.
  • opt (bool) – flag to compute optimal amplitudes. See DMDBase. Default is False.
  • d (int) – the new order for spatial dimension of the input snapshots. Default is 1.
fit(X)[source]

Compute the Dynamic Modes Decomposition to the input data.

Parameters:X (numpy.ndarray or iterable) – the input snapshots.
